caption: Figure 1: Samples from a mixture of three Gaussian modes generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics. Three axes are l2 distance from samples to the mean of the three modes. The samples are initialized in mode 0.
description: This figure visualizes the performance of three Langevin dynamics variants (vanilla, annealed, and chained) in sampling from a multimodal distribution (a mixture of three Gaussian modes).  The three axes represent the L2 distances between generated samples and the means of the three Gaussian modes.  The plots show the sample distribution at different iteration counts (1000, 10000, 100000, 1000000). By observing the progression of the plots, one can assess how effectively each method explores the different modes of the distribution, highlighting the mode-seeking tendency of vanilla and annealed Langevin Dynamics and the improved exploration offered by the chained approach.

caption: Figure 1: Samples from a mixture of three Gaussian modes generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics. Three axes are l2 distance from samples to the mean of the three modes. The samples are initialized in mode 0.
description: This figure visualizes the results of three different Langevin dynamics methods (vanilla, annealed, and chained) in sampling from a three-mode Gaussian mixture. Each subplot shows the distribution of samples generated after a specific number of iterations (1000, 10000, 100000, and 1000000). The three axes represent the squared Euclidean distance of each sample to the means of the three Gaussian modes.  The initial samples are all drawn from mode 0. The visualization allows comparison of how effectively each method explores and samples from the other modes. Vanilla Langevin Dynamics is seen to struggle to leave mode 0 even after a million iterations, while Annealed Langevin Dynamics shows some improvement but still struggles to reach the other modes. Chained Langevin Dynamics effectively explores all three modes more efficiently.

caption: Figure 7: Samples from a mixture distribution of the original and flipped images from the Fashion-MNIST dataset generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics. The samples are initialized as flipped images from Fashion-MNIST.
description: This figure shows the samples generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics from a bimodal distribution of Fashion-MNIST images. The leftmost column shows the initial samples (flipped images), and the other columns show samples after 3000, 10000, 30000, and 100000 iterations, respectively. The results demonstrate the ability of Chained Langevin Dynamics to capture both modes of the distribution, unlike vanilla and annealed methods.

caption: Figure 1: Samples from a mixture of three Gaussian modes generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics. Three axes are ℓ2 distance from samples to the mean of the three modes. The samples are initialized in mode 0.
description: This figure visualizes the performance of three Langevin dynamics variants (vanilla, annealed, and chained) in sampling from a three-mode Gaussian mixture distribution.  The three axes represent the squared Euclidean distance of generated samples to the means of each of the three modes.  The plots show the distribution of samples generated after 1000, 10000, 100000 and 1000000 iterations, with the initial samples drawn from a single mode (mode 0).  This illustrates the ability (or lack thereof) of each method to escape the initial mode and explore the other modes of the distribution.

caption: Figure 4: Samples from a mixture of three Gaussian modes generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics. Three axes are l2 distance from samples to the mean of the three modes. The samples are initialized in mode 1.
description: This figure visualizes the results of three different Langevin dynamics methods (vanilla, annealed, and chained) applied to sample from a three-mode Gaussian mixture. Each subfigure shows the samples generated after different numbers of iterations (T = 1000, 10000, 100000, 1000000). The three axes represent the L2 distances of each sample to the means of the three modes. The samples are initialized from mode 1 and the figure illustrates how the different methods converge towards the target distribution over time, exhibiting different mode-seeking properties.

caption: Figure 1: Samples from a mixture of three Gaussian modes generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics. Three axes are l2 distance from samples to the mean of the three modes. The samples are initialized in mode 0.
description: This figure visualizes the performance of three Langevin dynamics variants (vanilla, annealed, and chained) in sampling from a three-mode Gaussian mixture distribution.  Each subplot shows the samples generated after a certain number of iterations (1000, 10000, 100000, 1000000). The three axes represent the squared Euclidean distance of the samples to the mean of each of the three modes.  The initial samples are all drawn from mode 0. The visualization helps to understand how well each method explores and converges to the different modes of the distribution, highlighting the limitations of vanilla and annealed Langevin dynamics and demonstrating the effectiveness of the chained approach.

caption: Figure 7: Samples from a mixture distribution of the original and flipped images from the Fashion-MNIST dataset generated by vanilla, annealed, and chained Langevin dynamics. The samples are initialized as flipped images from Fashion-MNIST.
description: This figure shows the samples generated from a mixture distribution of original and flipped Fashion-MNIST images using three different Langevin dynamics methods: vanilla, annealed, and chained.  The samples are initialized as flipped images.  The figure visually demonstrates the performance of each method in capturing both modes of the bimodal distribution across different numbers of iterations (3000, 10000, 30000, 100000).

caption: Figure 8: Samples from a mixture distribution of the original and flipped images from the MNIST dataset generated by annealed and chained Langevin dynamics for T = 100000 iterations. The samples are initialized as the original or flipped images from MNIST.
description: This figure visualizes samples generated from a bimodal distribution (original MNIST digits and their flipped counterparts) using annealed and chained Langevin dynamics.  The experiment ran for 100,000 iterations.  The left-hand side shows samples initialized from the original MNIST digits, and the right-hand side shows samples initialized from flipped digits.  The results demonstrate the ability of the chained Langevin dynamics to effectively explore both modes of the distribution.

caption: Figure 9: Samples from a mixture distribution of the original and flipped images from the Fashion-MNIST dataset generated by annealed and chained Langevin dynamics for T = 100000 iterations. The samples are initialized as the original or flipped images from Fashion-MNIST.
description: This figure shows the samples generated by annealed and chained Langevin dynamics from a bimodal distribution of Fashion-MNIST images. The two modes are composed of original images and their flipped versions.  The figure demonstrates that after 100000 iterations, both methods are able to generate samples from both modes. Each subfigure shows a 20x20 grid of generated images.
